dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, from the jump, Host_A. It immediately says policymakers acknowledge globalization's "immense contribution to global inflation."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But then, almost in the very next breath, it pivots! It says, "Conversely, the main features of increased globalization... are proven drivers of *deflation*." So, is it pushing prices up or down? Make up your mind!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, almost in the very next breath, it pivots! It says, Conversely, the main features of increased globalization are proven drivers of deflation. So, is it pushing prices up or down? Make up your mind!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Globalization acted as a deflationary force by reducing labor and production costs. Likewise, the main features of deglobalization higher tariffs and other trade barriers, together with a shift from global to regional trade flows are known drivers of inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And then it throws in this statistic about US core goods inflation, saying it "decreased sharply, from more than 2% at the start of 2021 to less than 6% in mid-2022."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And then it throws in this statistic about U S core goods inflation, saying it decreased sharply, from more than two percent at the start of twenty twenty one to less than six percent in mid twenty twenty two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is no surprise, then, that core goods inflation in the United States has increased sharply, from less than 2% at the start of 2021 to 6% in mid-2022.

dialogue_turns.text: Wait, *less than 6%* is a decrease from 2%? Uh, my math ain't mathing, Host_A. That sounds like an increase. A pretty significant one, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, less than six percent is a decrease from two percent? Uh, my math ain't mathing, Host_A. That sounds like an increase. A pretty significant one, actually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then they predict a sustained *increase* in US inflation, but also that globalization will lead to "disinflationary pressures" and keep US inflation *lower* than the 1-2% range. So, both increasing and decreasing?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But deglobalization will likely contribute to inflationary pressures by increasing companies operating costs, thereby keeping US inflation higher than the 1-2% range recorded over most of the past decade and hovering near the Feds 2% target rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's like, which way is the wind blowing here? And then the geopolitical stuff. It says, uh, "strengthened economic ties with China's dynamic zero-COVID policy and Russia's thriving economy in Ukraine are expected to reduce prices."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then the Fed and other central banks. It talks about them combating "deflationary tendencies" and "dropping prices," and how lowering interest rates provides "deflation" to smaller countries.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To rein in surging price growth, the Federal Reserve and other central banks must adjust... When major central banks hike interest rates, they export inflation to smaller countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But it also says the Fed's current efforts to combat *deflation* by *lowering interest rates* will "increase demand and thus help curb price growth." Curb price growth when you're trying to fight deflation? That's, like, contradictory.
